2) Loss of grid

4) Loss of primary fibre communications
5) momentary electric arc in water (<20ms)
column8: Corrosion induced damage to the tension members of the cable

1) Automatic island mode
2) Proper material selection
3) Component sizing
column13: Repair/replace on site… but long lead time (~12mo)
column23:
1) Schedule regular visual inspection of components
2) design to reduce occurrence
column49: Corrosion could lead to two failure modes, either a mechanical failure due to loss of strength or an electrical fault. These should be divided into separate risks. This is a high risk for long term deployment due to energetic motions that make it difficult to  protect against water ingress especially at connection points. However a short term deployment is a good opportunity to test the system and check for potential signs of wear/water ingress.
column50:
All mechanical failure will lead to an electrical fault
The umbilical should be design to last one lifetime. 20yar minimal on 3signma, 7 occurrence is 32 years.  It seems the resultant risk should be not high.  Design target is medium which is possibly impossible and financially irresponsible to achieve.

1. On-going assessment and validation of the dynamic and motion response of the WEC, via means of analysis and measurements of the existing prototypes. 
2. Inspections and/or measurements on the WEC upon deployment for validation. 
3. The conclusions from the actions are to include any relevant safety margin due to the uncertainties on the collection of data, normal variability on the parameters.
4. Evidence of expected wear in the cable from testing/analysis, following the outcome of each of the action above, is within the design limits.
column49:
Failure cause is a long term effect, hence compatible to FLS design criteria. The occurrence class adjusted  to the class same as FLS.
Suggest text for recommended action:
1. On-going assessment and validation of the dynamic and motion response of the WEC, via means of analysis and measurements of the existing prototypes. 
2. Inspections and/or measurements on the WEC upon deployment for validation. 
3. The conclusions from the actions are to include any relevant safety margin due to the uncertainties on the collection of data, normal variability on the parameters.
4. Evidence of expected wear in the cable from testing/analysis, following the outcome of each of the action above, is within the design limits.

2. Design of umbilical to incorporate repairable weak link to allow for shorter repair time and reduced cost of failure
3) ) analysis: expected fish bite failures and detectability with regular inspections
